reviews.review_title: Stomach upset due to artificial colour in tea
reviews.review_body: Recently I find that my stomach is getting upset and found bloated after drinking this tea. To test the tea, I have added a spoon of this tea into cold water. Water colour changed to red, which means that artificial colours are added to this tea.

reviews.review_title: Perfect for that morning cup of tea
reviews.review_body: Highly quality leaf tea. Perfect for my morning cup of brew! Would highly recommend it for anyone who is looking for good tasty tea. The tea has the distinct flavor of like Assam teas and is strong so just need a small teaspoon full of serving for 1 cup. I would not recommend using this tea for making chai where the leaves are boiled for a few mins. Instead, make this the classic tea way - put in boiling water and let it stand for 3 to 5 mins before straining out the leaves, add little milk and sugar if needed and enjoy!Wanted something dark and hearty for making chai at home. Not as dusty and powdery as what you find at most Indian grocery stores, but not as intense either. Simmered in water, milk and masala for about 20 minutes, it produces a hearty and satisfying chai to my taste. When prepared this way, it has never produced any bitterness that some of the cheaper teas can leave behind.

Really wonder why people go gung-ho over this pathetic tea. I've read some rave reviews of this brand in foodies and other forums, but after personally using it, it never felt any way better than Tata or Red Label products.I would any day recommend Tata Tea Gold or Tata Ayurvedic Tea over this.

reviews.review_title: Naam ka Sacha. Wagh Bakri Sabse Acha.
reviews.review_body: The first sip made me fall in love with this tea. Super smooth, perfectly designed aromatic notes and holistically balanced flavour. It's far better than the loose tea sold in shops and also better than TATA Tea. If you want to have this tea with milk, use Amul Gold tetrapack milk for a 360 taste. You'll be amazed.
